questions.text: The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) prevents which type of dislocations when landing a jump while moving?
questions.correct_answer: D. Posterior dislocation of the femur
questions.explanation:
Ligaments

             Functions

Anterior cruciate ligament

Prevents posterior displacement of the femur on the tibia and the anterior displacement of the tibia on the femur

Posterior cruciate ligament

Prevents anterior displacement of the femur on the tibia and the posterior displacement of the tibia on the femur

Lateral collateral ligament

Lateral displacement of the tibia is prevented by the lateral collateral ligament of the knee joint.

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy in the emergency department post-motor vehicle accident shows hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status, and signs of pelvic trauma including ecchymoses around the hip region, perineal hematoma, and oedema. questions.text: A 49-year-old male with colorectal cancer metastasized to the liver (Segment VII) presents to the hepatic clinic on referral. Which vessels can be embolized to form collaterals, given that they drain deoxygenated blood from the liver into the inferior vena cava?

questions.text: A professor explains nephron physiology and the process of secretion and reabsorption. Tubular reabsorption is the process that moves solutes and water out of the filtrate and back into your bloodstream. This process is known as reabsorption because this is the second time they have been absorbed, the first time being when they were absorbed into the bloodstream from the digestive tract after a meal. Maximum absorption of HCO 3 - occurs in?

options.label: D
options.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Bicarbonate Mechanism
  • ➤ All the filtered HCO 3 – in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO 3 – utilizes the H + secreted into the renal tubules. H + secreted into the renal tubule, combines with filtered HCO 3 – forming carbonic acid (H 2 CO 3 ). Carbonic acid dissociates into carbon dioxide and water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Carbon dioxide and water enter the tubular cell. In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H + and HCO 3 – . HCO 3 – from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na + is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO 3 – combines with Na + to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO 3 ). Now, the H + is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na + . Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO 3 –. The reabsorption of filtered HCO 3 – is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids. Filtered bicarbonate can be reabsorbed only when it combines with H + .
  • ➤ All the filtered HCO 3 – in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO 3 – utilizes the H + secreted into the renal tubules.

  • ➤ In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H + and HCO 3 – . HCO 3 – from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na + is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO 3 – combines with Na + to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO 3 ). Now, the H + is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na + .
  • ➤ Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO 3 –. The reabsorption of filtered HCO 3 – is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with impaired consciousness for half an hour by his son in an emergency. His son reports that his father had a sudden, severe headache 2 hours back, which was described as the worst in his life. The patient has a history significant of hypertension and smoking. A head CT without contrast is normal. An emergency lumbar puncture is performed with an opening pressure of four times that of normal and an increased red blood cell count. How can you describe the relationship of CSF pressure to the venous pressure in the superior sagittal sinus in a healthy brain?

When even a relatively minor noxious stimulus is applied to the skin, it may activate autonomic neurons and produce evacuation of the bladder and rectum, sweating pallor, and blood pressure swings in addition to the withdrawal response. However, sometimes, it can be used to give paraplegic patients a degree of bladder and bowel control. Which one of the following is being described here?
Which of the following structures integrate impulses for eye-hand coordination?

questions.text: Which statement concerning visceral pain signals is correct ?

options.label: A
options.text: They are transmitted along sensory fibers that course mainly with sympathetic nerves in the abdomen and thorax

options.label: B
options.text: They are not stimulated by ischemia in visceral organs

options.label: C
options.text: They are transmitted only by the lightly myelinated δ-type A sensory fibers

questions.correct_answer: A. They are transmitted along sensory fibers that course mainly with sympathetic nerves in the abdomen and thorax
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Causes of Visceral Pain Ischemia: Substances released during ischemic reactions such as bradykinin and proteolytic enzymes stimulate the pain receptors of viscera. Chemical Stimuli: Chemical substances like acidic gastric juice, leak from ruptured ulcers into peritoneal cavity and produce pain. Spasm and Overdistention of Hollow Organs: Spastic contraction of smooth muscles in gastrointestinal tract and other hollow organs of viscera cause pain by stimulating the free nerve endings. Overdistention of hollow organs also causes pain. Pain sensation from thoracic and abdominal viscera is transmitted by sympathetic (thoracolumbar) nerves. Pain from esophagus, trachea and pharynx is carried by vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. Visceral pain signals from structures in the abdomen and thorax travel toward the spinal cord in association with fibers of the sympathetic system. Any stimulus that excites pain nerve endings in diffuse areas of the viscera can cause visceral pain. Visceral pain is transmitted through small type C pain fibers and, therefore, can transmit only the chronic-aching-suffering type of pain.

Overdistention of hollow organs also causes pain.
  • ➤ Ischemia: Substances released during ischemic reactions such as bradykinin and proteolytic enzymes stimulate the pain receptors of viscera.
  • ➤ Chemical Stimuli: Chemical substances like acidic gastric juice, leak from ruptured ulcers into peritoneal cavity and produce pain.
  • ➤ Spasm and Overdistention of Hollow Organs: Spastic contraction of smooth muscles in gastrointestinal tract and other hollow organs of viscera cause pain by stimulating the free nerve endings. Overdistention of hollow organs also causes pain.
  • ➤ Pain sensation from thoracic and abdominal viscera is transmitted by sympathetic (thoracolumbar) nerves. Pain from esophagus, trachea and pharynx is carried by vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves.
  • ➤ Visceral pain signals from structures in the abdomen and thorax travel toward the spinal cord in association with fibers of the sympathetic system.
  • ➤ Any stimulus that excites pain nerve endings in diffuse areas of the viscera can cause visceral pain.
  • ➤ Visceral pain is transmitted through small type C pain fibers and, therefore, can transmit only the chronic-aching-suffering type of pain.

CPS I CPS II
Rate-limiting enzyme of urea cycle Rate limiting step of pyrimidine synthesis
Found in mitochondria Found in cytosol

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male with type 1 diabetes presents in the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, weakness, nausea, and 1 episode of vomit. All ketone bodies can be detected by Rothera's test except:

Further examination showed hepatosplenomegaly and increased cholesterol esters and triglyceride levels in plasma. X-ray showed calcification of adrenals . The child most probably has a defect in which of the following enzymes ?

On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Ocular examination shows the following findings: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?

options.label: B

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of delirium and hydrophobia. She developed these features after having a tonic-clonic seizure. The patient claims she was bitten by a bat on the hand about a month ago. The patient eventually succumbs to respiratory failure and dies. At autopsy, viral particles can be identified throughout the brainstem and cerebellum. The necrosis of virally infected neurons in this patient is most likely mediated by which of the following processes, in addition to direct viral cytotoxicity?

options.label: D
options.text: Release of oxygen radicals from macrophages

questions.text: A forty-three-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of a lesion on his left hand. Examination of the dorsal surface of his left-hand shows a scaly erythematous lesion. A skin sample of the lesion shows abnormal keratinocytes covering the entire epidermis thickness. The arrows indicate apoptotic bodies in the image below. In this patient's skin cancer, which of the following proteins plays the most critical role in mediating programmed cell death?

A 45-year-old guy appears with a growing abdomen circumference and yellow skin and sclera. Hepatomegaly and jaundice are discovered on physical examination. The image shows a Prussian blue stain from a liver biopsy. What is the most important intracellular iron storage protein in this patient's hepatocytes?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ An iron-containing oxygen transport protein found in red blood cells. Reference ranges vary by source. Elevated in polycythemia vera and decreased in anaemia. It does not stain with Prussian blue.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man develops weakness, malaise, cough, bloody sputum, and night sweats. A chest X-ray reveals numerous apical densities bilaterally. Exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis is documented 20 years ago, and M. tuberculosis is identified in the sputum . The patient subsequently dies of respiratory insufficiency. The lungs are examined at autopsy, as shown in the image: Which of the following best characterizes the histopathologic features of this pulmonary lesion?
questions.explanation:
Disease  Cause  Tissue Reaction 
Tuberculosis  Mycobacterium tuberculosis  Caseating granuloma (tubercle); focus of activated macrophages (epithelioid cells), rimmed by fibroblasts, lymphocytes, histiocytes, occasional Langhans giant cells; central necrosis with amorphous granular debris; acid-fast bacilli
Leprosy  Mycobacterium leprae Acid-fast bacilli in macrophages; noncaseating granulomas 
Syphilis  Treponema pallidum Gumma; microscopic to grossly visible lesion, enclosing wall of histiocytes; plasma cell infiltrate; central cells are necrotic without loss of cellular outline 
Cat-scratch disease  Gram-negative bacillus  Rounded or stellate granuloma containing central granular debris and recognizable neutrophils; giant cells uncommon 
Sarcoidosis  unknown etiology  Noncaseating granulomas with abundant activated macrophages 
Crohn disease (inflammatory bowel disease) Immune reaction against intestinal bacteria, possibly self-antigens  Occasional noncaseating granulomas in the wall of the  intestine, with dense chronic inflammatory infiltrate

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of severe abdominal pain and headache for the past two days. He has a history of myalgia and several episodes of vomiting. His parents self-medicated with paracetamol, but the patient had no relief. A dengue NS -1 antigen test was ordered which came out positive. A 48-Year-old male, a chronic alcoholic, presents to the hospital with sudden onset fever, chills, and rigour. He underwent a liver transplant 2 weeks ago after developing liver cirrhosis and fulminant hepatic failure . His heart rate is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and SpO 2 is 87%. questions.text: The trial of Mr. Gupta is in court now. After having thoroughly studied the case, the judge declared that a magistrate inquest was not needed in this case. What among the following could be the offence Mr. Gupta is being charged for?

Sr. No. Feature Magistrate inquest Police inquest

3. Types of cases handled Can hold inquest in all cases of suspicious deaths Cannot hold an inquest in cases of death in custody, jail, police firing or dowry deaths

10. Quality of investigation Superior to police inquest Inferior to Magistrate inquest

questions.text: The body of the 25-year-old who had allegedly committed suicide by hanging in the hostel premises has been brought for autopsy. The doctor decides to collect the specimens via the most commonly choosen method, though the anatomical relations of the organs cannot be maintained by this method. How will the organs be collected if he has chosen Virchow's method?

options.label: C
options.text: Organs are removed one by one

options.label: D
options.text: In situ dissection combined with en bloc removal

questions.correct_answer: C. Organs are removed one by one
questions.explanation:
Autopsy Techniques   Advantage Disadvantage
Letulle’s

Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block
  • The best technique to see relations amongst organs
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other
  • Rapid technique
 Difficult to handle large mass.

Ghon’s

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks (en block)

 This method can also be used in Infants  

Virchow’s

Organs are removed one by one

 Most commonly used technique (easier to perform) Anatomical relations of organs are not preserved
Rokitansky In situ dissection (inside the body itself)

Good for

  • Infected bodies like HIV, Hepatitis B (prevents spreading of infection)
  • Radiation hazards
  • Fetal brain dissection

A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with chronic complaints of burning sensation and discomfort over the epigastrium. He has a duodenal ulcer and H. pylori infection on endoscopy and biopsy. He has been prescribed proton pump inhibitors (PPI) & advised to follow up. Which of the following is a side effect of prolonged intake of PPI?
questions.correct_answer: A. Decreasing the effect of clopidogrel

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with the complaints of multiple episodes of diarrhoea approximately for the past 2 months accompanied by weight loss. Occasional blood streaks are noted in the stool. On examination, the patient looks weak with mild pallor. Ulcerative colitis is suspected. What will be the earliest radiological finding on barium enema?

You are a first-year medicine resident rotating in the department of haematology. A group of patients came for follow-up after having allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Which of the following has the least 5-year survival rate following allogeneic bone marrow transplantation?
questions.explanation:
Acute myelocytic leukaemia

 

    40-60%

 
Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

 

    40-50%

 
C.M.L. Chronic phase

 

       70%

 
C.M.L. Blast crisis

 

       15%

 
C.L.L.

 

       50%

 
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

       40%

 
Severe combined immunodeficiency, Aplastic Anaemia, Thalassemia

 

       90%

questions.text: A 30 years old man is brought to the hospital by ambulance after a road traffic accident. He was an unrestrained passenger and sustained considerable trauma. He was given a blood transfusion in the OT and developed tachycardia, hypotension (BP 70/40 mm of Hg), temperature 100°F and haematuria within 10 minutes of starting the transfusion. Which of the following is most likely the reason for his presenting symptoms?

A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to an inability to swallow and hoarseness for 3 hours. His wife reports multiple episodes of vomiting and lightheadedness for the last few days. Physical examination reveals gait ataxia, miosis and ptosis on the left side, along with reduced pain and temperature sensations on the right side of the body. Deviation of the uvula to the right side is also seen. Which of the following arteries is most likely affected in this patient?

A 14-year-old boy presents to the neurology clinic with walking difficulty and bilateral foot deformity. There is no history of speaking difficulty, nystagmus, diplopia and cardiopulmonary problems. Vital signs are within normal range. On physical examination, thickened peripheral nerves and sensory gait ataxia is observed. The patient is unable to dorsiflex the foot. A typical onion bulb appearance is noted on a biopsy of the nerve. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Charcot Marie Tooth disease is a hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy. It occurs due to the defective proteins involved in myelin sheath structure and function. The most common type is CMT1A which is caused by PMP22 gene duplication. It is characterised by the following: Foot deformity (pes cavus, hammer toe) Motor deficit (foot drop) Sensory deficit (ataxia) Charcot Marie Tooth disease were called as hereditary motor and sensory neuropathies (HMSN) . questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents in OPD with a history of swelling and severe pain in his great toe since last night. On examination, tenderness is positive, and warmth of the joint is noticed. The physician suggested a microscopic examination of the synovial fluid of the affected joint; hence, aspiration of synovial fluid was done. On Polarised microscopy, the following image is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 33-year-old male presents to the general physician setting with complaints of morning stiffness associated with increased pain intensity after periods of inactivity and on/off pain in the buttock region. He also complained of photosensitivity and blurring of vision. On examination, the slit lamp showed findings of keratic precipitates on the back of the cornea. What could be the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency for a 3-day history of dark urine and abdominal distension. On examination, she has a normal mental status; icterus is present, heart and lungs are normal. Her speech is slurred and monotonous. Examination shows a broad-based gait and a low-frequency tremor in her left hand. Lab findings include: Hematocrit: 26 Reticulocytes: 5% Platelets: 1.3 lakhs Alk. Phos: 30 units/L ALT: 110 units/L AST: 220 units/L Total bilirubin:13mg% (Direct:4 mg) HbsAg is positive Hepatitis ‘A’&’C’ are negative. The urine drug screen is negative. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a nodular appearing liver and an enlarged spleen. Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A fifty years old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of abdominal pain. The patient leads a sedentary lifestyle but does not smoke or drink alcohol. He likes to eat out, and his diet consists of fried foods daily. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and his BMI is 32. Abdominal examination shows an enlarged, non-tender liver. The liver span, on light percussion, is 20 cm. An abdominal ultrasound is performed, which shows that his liver echogenicity is more than that of the renal cortex and spleen. What is the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:

Overweight/ Obesity

Insulin resistance

Sedentary lifestyle

Increased waist circumference

Genetics

Dyslipidemia

Aging

Glucose intolerance

Diabetes mellitus

Hypertension

Lipodystrophy

Adiponectin

questions.text: A 61 years old former heavy smoker with a known case of chronic bronchitis presents to the emergency room with a history of shortness of breath which gradually increased in severity and presented even at rest. He also had peripheral chest pain. He has been undergoing treatment for 3-4 years. The complication least likely to occur in this case is?
A 25-year-old footballer was elbowed in the chest by a rival defender during ball possession. Following the chest trauma, the player collapses and dies . The most probable cause of death is ?

The age of onset of OCD seems to have a bimodal distribution, with a peak in childhood (at approximately 10 years of age) and another in early adulthood. There is evidence that brain activity differs in adults with childhood- onset OCD versus adult-onset OCD. Brain areas involved with obsessive compulsive disorder include all except:
questions.explanation:
Neuroanatomical Structures Involved in OCD
  1. Orbito-frontal Cortex
  2. Caudate Nucleus (which is a part of Basal Ganglia)
  3. Thalamus

Psychiatric Disorders Brain Areas involved
1. Anxiety disorders
  1. Locus ceruleus
  2. Raphe nucleus
  3. Caudate nucleus
  4. Temporal cortex
  5. Frontal cortex
2. Depression Damage to the left frontal lobe
3. Alzheimer's disease Hippocampus

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy with a feminine mannerism is presented in the psychiatric office by his mother, who claims that she has seen him occasionally dressing like a female . His friends have also noticed a change in his behavior; he was bullied in high school. On investigation, the patient claims that he knows he is a male and never considers himself of the opposite gender. He denies the urge to change his sexual characteristics. This patient is most likely suffering from which of the following?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Paraphilias are disorders of sexual preference in which sexual arousal occurs persistently and significantly in response to objects which are not a part of normal sexual Arousal .

questions.text: Sleep is not a single process; there are several distinct types of sleep. These different types of sleep differ both qualitatively and quantitatively. Sleep is not a passive process; during sleep, there is a high degree of brain activation and metabolism. Which one of the following phenomenon is not associated with slow wave sleep?

A recent study showed that delirium and associated clinical features are often present and may be prominent. The EEG usually shows diffuse slowing of background activity, although patients with delirium caused by alcohol or sedative-hypnotic withdrawal have low-voltage fast activity. All of the following are features of delirium except:

options.label: B
options.text: Most common organic mental disorder with an chronic onset

options.label: C
options.text: After cataract surgery it is known as black patch delirium

questions.correct_answer: B. Most common organic mental disorder with an chronic onset

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman attended the outpatient department with a lump measuring 5x4cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. A fine needle aspiration cytology of the lump revealed invasive ductal carcinoma . As a result, she underwent a Patey's modified radical mastectomy. During the procedure, which structure is preserved?
questions.explanation:
Variants of MRM
Auchincloss Procedure Removes all breast tissue, nipple-areola complex, skin and level I & II axillary lymph nodes
PATEY’S modification Pectoralis minor is divided usually at its insertion in the coracoid process and removed to allow complete dissection of level III axillary lymph nodes
Scanlon’s Modification Pectoralis minor is divided instead of removed. Division of pectoralis minor allows complete removal of level III axillary lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of fever for 1 month and generalized weakness. She also presents with an anterior neck swelling for 4 years which rapidly progressed in the past 3-4 months, accompanied by pain over the swelling, and hoarseness of voice . The patient further reported a history of recent weight loss and decreased appetite . She denied dysphagia, dyspnea, and any history of cancer in the family. Prior medical history was described as non-significant. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with active alcoholism and chronic hepatitis C presented to the emergency department with hematemesis and hematochezia started 5 days ago. The patient was alert, tachycardic, and hypotensive . Splenomegaly is noted. U pper GI endoscopy showed multiple esophageal varices, mild portal hypertensive gastropathy, and no gastric varices . Which of the following agents is recommended for the medical treatment?

A 39-year old female came to the OPD complaining of pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen for the past 5 days. The patient was further evaluated, and CT abdomen was done. What is your diagnosis based on the sign shown in the CT image ?

A 53-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of dysphagia and hematemesis . Dysphagia affects more solids than liquids. An endoscopic evaluation reveals a mass lesion in the gastroesophageal junction . Which of the following options is most likely associated with tumorsof the gastroesophageal junction?
questions.explanation:
Type Adenocarcinoma of Location
Type I Distal esophagus 1-5 cm above the gastroesophageal (GE) junction
Type II Real Cardia 1 cm above and 2 cm below the gastroesophageal junction
Types III Sub-Cardinal Stomach 2-5 cm below GE

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is admitted for asymptomatic renal stones . She received extensive resection of the small intestine due to strangulating obstructive ileus 7 years ago. She has a strong family history of renal stones. A plain film of the kidney, ureter, and bladder and a CT scan revealed bilateral renal stones (right 4 mm, left 10 mm). Which of the following could have predisposed the patient to develop urolithiasis?
questions.explanation:
Changes seen in Terminal Ileal Resection
  • Unabsorbed fatty acids bind with calcium. Increased concentration of free oxalates (oxalates bind with calcium normally and therefore escape without intestinal absorption)- Free oxalates are absorbed- Oxalate kidney stones
  • Vitamin B12 Malabsorption- Megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Bile salts Malabsorption-watery diarrhoea
  • Decreased bile salts in the bile−
    • Cholesterol gall stones
    • Steatorrhea and Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the medical outpatient department with complaints of abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea for the last two months. He is afebrile and vitally stable. He looks pale and has oral ulcers. His abdominal examination is unremarkable. On further evaluation, in barium contrast studies, the hose pipe appearance of the intestine is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
In which of the following conditions Oschner-Sherren's regimen is used as management?

A 30-year old man presents to the emergency department with extreme abdominal pain radiating to his groin for the last one hour. The ultrasound examination revealed mild hydronephrosis bilaterally . Non-enhanced computer tomography is then performed and shows a 10-mm hyperdense picture in the left ureter topography and a 9-mm hyperdense image in the right ureter topography , consistent with a diagnosis of bilateral ureterolithiasis . Given the clinical feature, which nerve carries the referred pain from the ureteric colic to the groin?

A 20-year-old man presents to a primary care physician complaining of chest discomfort for the last ten days . His primary care physician provides symptomatic treatment, which gives an initial improvement in symptoms. Afterwards, his chest discomfort started again, and he developed progressive dyspnea with exertion . A CT chest reveals a round, well-demarcated mass in the middle mediastinal compartment. Which of the following is rare enough to be included in the middle mediastinal masses found in the patient discussed above?

A 15-month-old boy is brought to the hospital for a burn injury. Baby fell into a tub of hot water , father pulled him out and poured water at room temparture over affected areas of lower extremities, abdomen and torso. The burns were initially described as not too bad but later developed into blisters. The best method to assess burns caused by boiling water in a child is?
questions.correct_answer: C. Modified Lund and Browder chart

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient presented with complaints of painful nodules on the back and upper limbs for several years . She reported the growth of some nodules and an increase in number over time. The patient is obese and has a BMI of 37 . On physical examination, skin-coloured subcutaneous nodules all over the upper limbs and on the back were found, as shown in the image below: Surgical removal of the painful nodules and anatomopathological examination was performed, which confirmed the proliferation of well-differentiated and uniform adipocytes sitting on a fibrovascular network . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 45-year-old male presents to the surgical emergency department with a history of loss of consciousness and slurred speech for the last 12 hours. The patient is a known smoker with a 20-pack-year history. The patient is normal and reports that he suddenly fell while walking in his house . He lost consciousness for 5 minutes, after which the patient developed slurred speech. On examination, the patient had unilateral hemiparesis, which later progressed to unilateral hemiplegia. Which of the following is the most common cause of neurological deterioration in the case mentioned above ?
Which structure is most likely responsible for the copious dark blood encountered during a bedside tracheostomy in a patient with head trauma?

A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of throat pain and increasing difficulty swallowing food for the past 5 months. He has also had episodic left ear pain for the past 3 months. Further history reveals hypertension, chronic smoking, and alcohol. Family history is positive for laryngeal cancer. Examination shows left cervical lymphadenopathy. Oropharyngeal examination shows a 3 cm ulcerating mass infiltrating the floor of the mouth. The senior physician recommends the commando operation. Which of the following statements best describes the commando operation?

options.label: A
options.text: Abdominoperineal resection of the rectum for carcinoma

options.label: B
options.text: Resection of all level 1 to 4 neck lymph nodes

options.label: D
options.text: Excision of carcinoma of the jaw and lymph nodes

questions.correct_answer: D. Excision of carcinoma of the jaw and lymph nodes

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presented to the emergency department with sudden and continuous pain in his left testicle after an injury while playing sports. The pain was accompanied by radiating pain to the abdomen and left inguinal area, nausea, and vomiting for more than 12 hours. The patient had no prior history of this kind of pain. Upon examination, no testes were found in the left scrotum. What is the appropriate surgical procedure for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Can be delayed 24 hours and limited to the affected side

options.label: B
options.text: Can be delayed but should include the asymptomatic side

options.label: C
options.text: Should be immediate and limited to the affected side

options.label: D
options.text: Should be immediate and include the asymptomatic side

questions.correct_answer: D. Should be immediate and include the asymptomatic side

questions.text: You are the 2nd year PG in the surgery department assisting the chief surgeon in Exploratory laparotomy for a patient with severe abdominal trauma. The patient was successfully managed, and while closing the abdomen after a midline laparotomy , you were asked by your chief to suture the incision. What length of suture will you choose to close the incision ?

options.label: A
options.text: Twice the length of the incision

options.label: B
options.text: 4 times the length of the incision

options.label: C
options.text: 6 times the length of the incision

options.label: D
options.text: 8 times the length of the incision

questions.correct_answer: B. 4 times the length of the incision

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with a history of end-stage renal disease from focal segmental glomerulosclerosis was managed solely with steroid therapy until he underwent a living-unrelated donor kidney transplant after a progressive deterioration in renal function. The most probable malignancy that can occur in this individual post-transplant is :
questions.correct_answer: B. Squamous cell carcinoma of skin
questions.explanation:
COMPLICATIONS OF IMMUNOSUPPRESSION

INFECTION MALIGNANCY NON-IMMUNE SIDE EFFECTS
  • High risk of infection by virusesQ (CMV InfectionQ)during first 6 months
  • Recipient derived infectionsQare more common than donor derived infections
  • Bacterial infection- during first monthQ
  • Polyoma BK virus is associated with a progressive nephropathy and Ureteral obstruction
  • JC virus has been found to be associated with progressive multimodal leukoencephalopathy
  • Chemoprophylaxis is important in high risk patients
  • Pre-transplant vaccination against community acquired infection should be considered
  • MC malignancy in transplant recipient: Skin cancerQ (SCC)
  • Increased risk of PTLD & Kaposi sarcoma and other virally mediated tumours
  • Hypertension & chronic allograft nephropathy-Calcineurin inhibitorsQ
  • New onset diabetes - Tacrolimus or steroidsQ
  • Hyperlipidemia, anemia & accelerated cardiovascular diseaseQ
  • Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death in transplant survivorsQ

questions.text: A 22-year-old otherwise healthy male presented to the ER following a single gunshot wound to the left groin. On examination, the patient was hemodynamically stable but had no palpable lower extremity pulses on the injured side. The ankle-brachial index confirmed an arterial injury (<0.9). On immediate exploration, a transected superficial left femoral artery was identified. Which of the following is the suture with maximum tensile strength and minimum tissue reaction that can be used in this patient?

An 85-year-old woman was brought to the emergency room by her son due to a penetrating stab injury on the anterior neck. A kitchen knife was deeply stuck in the midline of the anterior neck, but there was no active bleeding. The patient was semiconscious; bradycardia and hypotension were noted. Which of the following is the most likely reason?

A 24-year-old married woman has been trying to reduce her weight for the past 3 months. Her BMI is 31 kg/m 2 . However, she continues to eat high-fat and high-calorie foods regularly. Menarche occurred at age 14. Her first child was born at the age of 22. She has also been using oral contraceptives for the past 5 years . Which of the following factors is associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer in this patient?

A mother brings her 4-month-old baby to the clinic after she noticed asymmetry of thigh folds. Upon asking about the complications during pregnancy, she states that except for the breech presentation of the baby, there was no other complication during the pregnancy. On the examination of the child, thigh folds are asymmetrical . Abduction of the thigh produces a clunk sound. Keeping in view the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the treatment of the choice for this baby?

A 38-year-old Lorry driver driving a long distance decides to take a nap, parks his vehicle on the side of the road, and sleeps under the lorry . Unfortunately, another lorry driver driving under the influence of alcohol loses control and hit this lorry on the backside . The patient is brought to the emergency 2 hours after the incident. Proximal limb amputation is planned for this patient. What is the normal permissible ischemia time?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a road traffic accident two hours ago. He is not able to put weight on his left lower leg. His blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, his pulse is 105/min, and his respiratory rate is 18/min. On physical examination , abrasions are seen on the chest and lower extremities. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. The pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. An x-ray of the lower limbs is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture of the shaft of the femur

options.label: D
options.text: Fracture of the neck of the femur with injury to femoral vessels

questions.correct_answer: A. Posterior dislocation of the hip

questions.text: A 15-year-old school-going boy presents to the clinic with the complaint of right knee pain for the past few days. He denies any trauma. On examination, right knee swelling is noted. An x-ray of the lower limb is ordered. X-ray shows the following findings as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a head injury from a road traffic accident. He is semiconscious with a GCS of 7/15. The patient has multiple lacerations on his head. The patient's CT brain was done, revealing a convex-shaped hyperdense lesion that doesn’t cross the suture line. The patient is planned for endotracheal intubation. The anesthesiology resident used his right hand on the neck to view the glottis properly while performing endotracheal intubation. The manoeuvre used in this case is:

A 45-year-old female is being posted for a right-modified radical mastectomy under general anaesthesia. Induction of anaesthesia is done with Inj. Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV. Which of the following is the underlying mechanism of these observed findings?

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a known case of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and pancreatic carcinoma with liver secondaries on palliative treatment. He is attending the pain clinic regularly and getting tablets of morphine for cancer pain. He was not able to come and get treatment for the past 3 days. Which of the following symptom will the patient suffer for using the drug involved in this case for 3 days?

A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department complaining of pain in the right inguinal region. His blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 110/minute. Physical examination revealed a mass consistent with an inguinal hernia. He was scheduled to be operated on while under general anaesthesia. The anaesthesiologist decided to use succinylcholine for intubation and anaesthesia induction. Which of the following side effects is anticipated for this patient?

A 40-year-old man comes to the hospital with his wife and presents with acute onset of severe pain in his right great toe. He has long-standing diabetes mellitus and hypertension. questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a known case of diabetes mellitus type-2, presents to the emergency department with complaints of mild abdominal pain over the left side of the abdomen for the last 2 days. questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at a gynecology clinic seeks contraception advice. She's been married for 5 years, has 2 kids, and wants a one-time long-acting contraceptive. She may want another child later. Which contraception is not recommended for her?

A 25-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On per speculum examination, there is mucopurulent discharge extruding from the cervix. The discharge, when examined under the microscope, shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely organism?

A 45-year-old woman who had two normal pregnancies 13 and 20 years ago presents with the complaint of amenorrhea for 9 months. She expresses the desire to become pregnant again. After exclusion of pregnancy, which of the following is the next best test indicated in the evaluation of this patient’s amenorrhea?

A primigravida presents to her antenatal clinic at 24 weeks . As a routine, she gets tested for urine albumin and glucose with a dipstick and tests positive for glucose . Her oral glucose tolerance test ( OGTT) was normal , and she has no past or family history of diabetes. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: A. No further intervention is needed
questions.explanation:
Glucosuria
  • Glucosuria in pregnancy can be a normal finding.
  • It is a physiological increase in glomerular filtration and impaired tubular resorptive capacity for filtered glucose.
  • The best next step is an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).
  • If it is normal, then gestational diabetes is ruled out.

questions.text: Antenatal ultrasound at 22 weeks in a primigravida suggests an anterior grade 1 placenta with cord vessels ending a few mm away from the placental margin. This type of presentation is associated with an increased risk for which of the following complication?

options.label: B
options.text: Can cause fetal exsanguinations before labour due to blood loss

options.label: C
options.text: Torsion of the umbilical cord and fetal death

questions.correct_answer: C. Torsion of the umbilical cord and fetal death
questions.explanation:
Definition Torsion of the umbilical cord refers to the twisting or rotation of the cord around its axis, compromising blood flow.
Mechanism The umbilical cord can become twisted due to fetal movements, maternal movements, or the fetus passing through the loop.
Impact on Blood Flow Twisting can lead to compression or kinking of blood vessels in the cord, causing reduced blood flow to the fetus.
Clinical Presentation 1. Fetal distress: Reduced oxygen and nutrient supply 2. Changes in fetal heart rate patterns on monitoring.
Diagnosis Ultrasonography can show signs of cord torsion, such as a twisted appearance or "whirlpool" sign.
Management Intrauterine Resuscitation: If fetal distress is detected, interventions to improve fetal oxygenation. Delivery: If signs of fetal compromise worsen or in the case of fetal demise.
Risk Factors Multiple pregnancies, long umbilical cord, excessive amniotic fluid (polyhydramnios), fetal movement, and maternal obesity.
Complications 1. Fetal distress and hypoxia 2. Stillbirth (rarely) 3. Cord avulsion (cord detaching from placethe nta)
Prevention Preventing excessive fetal movement through medications (for preterm labor) or managing conditions like polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A woman presents at 8 weeks of pregnancy for evaluation. Her investigations are done, and her blood group turns out B-negative . As a follow-up, her husband’s blood grouping is done, which is B positive . Anti-D prophylaxis should be given to such patients in all except which of the following condition?

options.label: A
options.text: If she opts for a medical abortion

options.label: B
options.text: If amniocentesis is done at 16 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: If the baby’s Direct Coomb’s test at birth is positive

options.label: D
options.text: If a manual removal of the placenta is done at delivery

questions.correct_answer: C. If the baby’s Direct Coomb’s test at birth is positive
questions.explanation:
Indications for prophylactic administration of anti-D immune globulin for Rh(D)-negative patients*

  • At 28-32 weeks gestation as a part of RAADP (Routine Antenatal Anti-D Prophylaxis)
  • <72 hours after delivery of Rh(D)-positive infant
  • <72 hours after spontaneous abortion
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Threatened abortion
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • Chorionic villus sampling, amniocentesis
  • Abdominal trauma
  • 2nd- & 3rd-trimester bleeding
  • External cephalic version

questions.text: 32-year-old pregnant woman at 11 weeks of gestational age has high blood pressure reading of 150/100 mm Hg, repeat BP is 160/90 mm Hg, and urinalysis is negative for protein. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic Preeclampsia Eclampsia
Definition A condition characterized by high blood pressure (hypertension) and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation. A severe complication of preeclampsia, characterized by the onset of seizures in a pregnant woman with hypertension and proteinuria.
Seizures Seizures are not present in preeclampsia. Seizures are a defining feature of eclampsia.
Proteinuria Proteinuria is a hallmark feature of preeclampsia. Proteinuria is present in eclampsia, as it is a severe form of preeclampsia. However, not all women with preeclampsia will progress to eclampsia.
Hypertension Hypertension is a characteristic of preeclampsia. Hypertension is also present in eclampsia, and it is often a part of the diagnostic criteria for preeclampsia.
Onset of Seizures Seizures do not occur in preeclampsia. Seizures typically occur after the diagnosis of preeclampsia, indicating the progression to eclampsia.
Convulsions Convulsions are not seen in preeclampsia. Convulsions (seizures) are a defining feature of eclampsia.
Management Prompt management and close monitoring are essential to prevent the progression of preeclampsia to eclampsia. Immediate and aggressive management is necessary to control seizures and manage the underlying preeclampsia.
Maternal and Fetal Risks Preeclampsia poses risks to both the mother and the fetus, including complications like placental abruption, liver and kidney dysfunction, and fetal growth restriction. Eclampsia carries additional risks due to the presence of seizures, such as cerebral hemorrhage and maternal or fetal injury during convulsions.
Treatment Treatment involves antihypertensive medications to manage blood pressure and close monitoring of the mother and baby's condition. Treatment includes magnesium sulfate administration to control and prevent seizures, along with managing hypertension and other preeclampsia-related complications.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl child is brought by her mother to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of poor physical growth. She looks pale, has hair loss, and frequently falls ill. Her diet is vegetarian . On examination, her sexual characteristics are delayed. Her Hb is 8 g/dL. Which element is deficient in this girl?

A 28-year-old female primigravida gives birth to an infant at the gestational age of 39 weeks, and the baby's birth weight is 1500 grams. The cry is delayed and weak. On examination, reflexes are sluggish, and on the U/S brain, no solid or cystic lesion was seen. Mild hydrocephalus dilated all four brain edema grade 2 parenchymal and IVH, including the germinal matrix. Grade 2 intracranial hemorrhage is ruled out. At a CT scan of the brain, extensive white matter edema involving the subcortical regions of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes caused effacement of the right lateral ventricle. No hemorrhagic density is identified. Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy involving the frontal, parietal, and temporal regions. Which part of the brain is most commonly affected?

A 3-day-old neonate who is preterm is brought to the emergency department by his mother with complaints of poor feeding, fever, and lethargy for 3 days. The mother also complained about reduced milk production. On examination, the baby has tachycardia and tachypnea; his temperature is 39°C, a blood sugar level of 47 mg/dl, a pulse rate of 126 beats per minute, and decreased urine output. The on-duty consultant asks to send all relevant investigations. Which of the following will be most significant in the patient’s current pathology?
questions.explanation:
Definition Neonatal sepsis is a clinical syndrome characterized by signs and symptoms of infection in the first 28 days of life.
Classification Neonatal sepsis can be categorized as early-onset (within the first 72 hours) or late-onset (after 72 hours).
Etiology Neonatal sepsis can be caused by bacterial, viral, or fungal pathogens. Most common bacteria include Group B Streptococcus, Escherichia coli, and Listeria.
Risk Factors Premature birth, low birth weight, prolonged rupture of membranes, maternal infection, lack of prenatal care, invasive procedures, and more.
Clinical Presentation Early-onset: Respiratory distress, apnea, temperature instability, poor feeding. Late-onset: Fever, poor feeding, irritability, jaundice.
Laboratory and Imaging Blood culture is the gold standard for diagnosis. Other tests: Complete blood count, C-reactive protein, lumbar puncture (if meningitis is suspected).
Treatment Empiric antibiotic therapy is initiated immediately after obtaining cultures. Antibiotics are adjusted based on culture results and sensitivities.
Prevention Intrapartum antibiotics for mothers at risk to prevent early-onset sepsis. Proper hygiene, infection control measures in neonatal units.
Complications Mortality, neurodevelopmental delays, septic shock, multi-organ failure, long-term disabilities, hearing loss, visual impairment.

questions.text: A boy was delivered at 30 weeks gestation, with no cry and no breathing . The pediatric resident started with the resuscitation protocol, provided warmth and maintained temperature , positioned the airway, and stimulated the baby . After these steps, a resident noticed that the baby was still apneic and the heart rate was < 100/min. What would be the next single best step of management?

A 6-month-old twin born with a gap of 6 minutes is presented to the clinic by his m other. He complains that t he elderly baby is more playful and alert and reacts well, while the younger one is the opposite . He is not very playful and cries . The mother also complains that the younger baby cannot Roll front to back and back to front on the bed. Also, he can not recognize his parents , and he has no anxiety about strangers . The mother gets worried and asks the doctor about her younger baby. What is the 'red flag sign' in developmental milestones in the baby ?

options.label: A
options.text: No sitting with support at 6 months

questions.correct_answer: D. No Social smile by 6 months

Areas 6 months 9 months 12 months
Gross motor
  • Not rolling over
  • Not holding up head when lying on the  tummy or supported to sit
  • Not sitting without support
  • Not bearing weight on legs when held to stand
  • Not crawling
  • Not standing with support
Cognitive, fine motor and self-care
  • Not reaching for and holding on to objects
  • Has difficulty getting things to mouth
  • Not transferring objects from one hand to another
  • Not picking up small objects with thumb and index finger
  • Not searching for things that she sees you hide
  • Not feeding self with finger foods or holding a cup or bottle
Speech and language
  • Not making vowel sounds (e.g. ah, oh, eh)
  • Not making consonant sounds (e.g., mama, baba, dada)
  • Not responding to own name
  • Not pointing to make requests
  • Not using gestures (e.g. waving bye bye)
Social
  • Not smiling at familiar faces
  • Not laughing or making squealing sounds
  • Not looking where parent points
  • Not recognizing familiar people
  • Does not enjoy social games (e.g., peak a boo)

A 5-year-old girl is brought to ER after her brother threw a caterpillar into her right eye. On examination, she has conjunctival redness, swelling and decreased vision. She also complains of ocular pain. The visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Numerous caterpillar hairs are embedded in the periocular skin, eyelids, and the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva of the right eye. Which of the following is a likely complication seen in this patient?
A patient came to the OPD with recent onset photophobia within 24 hours and a sloughing corneal ulcer. There is a greenish ulcer base. Which of the following can be the causative organism?

A 12-year-old male child presents to the emergency department with a high-grade fever for the past 3 days. He also complains of sore throat, watery eyes, difficulty swallowing, and joint pain . On examination, vesicles inside the mouth, nares, and around the anal region are seen. Ten days ago, he took tetracycline for the treatment of facial acne . Keeping in view the most likely cause of his current symptoms, which of the following drug is not responsible for his current symptoms ?
questions.explanation:
Antibiotics

Antifungals

Antivirals
  • Sulfonamides, e.g., cotrimoxizole; beta-lactams i.e. Penicillins, cephalosporins
  • Imidazole antifungals
  • Nevirapine (non-nucleoside reverse-transcriptase inhibitor)
Allopurinol

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID)

(oxicam type mainly)
  • Naproxen
  • Ibuprofen
Anti-convulsants
  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Phenobarbital
  • Valproic acid
  • Lamotrigine

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents with a fever and headache. She also complains of vaginal itching and dysuria. When asked, she says that she recently became sexually active. Physical examination reveals tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and red, pustular, painful vesicles on her labia majora. Which of the following additional findings can be caused by the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic Syphilis Herpes Chancroid LGV Donovanosis
Primary lesion Papule Vesicle Pustule Papule, vesicle pustule Papule
Number of lesions Usually 1 Multiple Multiple Single Variable
Diameter 5-15 mm 1-2 mm Variable 2-10 mm Variable
Edges Sharply demarcated elevated Erythematous Polycyclic Undermined Ragged Elevated Round or oval Elevated Irregular
Depth Superficial or deep Superficial Excavated Superficial Or deep Elevated
Base Smooth Non-purulent Covered with serous exudate Erythematous Purulent Dirty grey Base Variable Red Velvety Bleeds easily
Induration Buttonhole None Not indurated Not indurated Not indurated
Lymphadenopathy Shotty lymph nodes Palpable tender Large inflamed bubo Bubos - inflammatory No lymphadenopathy.
Pain Painless Painful Painful Bubos - tender Painless

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of vaginal discomfort for the past several days. She also complains of mild itch and painful intercourse. She had menopause three years ago. She uses estrogen creams for her symptoms, but that does not seem to work. On examination, the introital mucosa and labia minora have a whitish-pink appearance. Abnormal wrinkles and a small tear on the right labia minora are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old Bengali male presents to the clinic complaining of painless nodules over the face. The face is erythematous, and the surface of some of the large nodules is discolored. On examination, multiple nodules are noted, as shown below: Sensations are intact, and the PPD test is negative. He gives a history of insect bites in the past while he went to the jungle for work. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Leprosy Hypopigmented hypo aesthetic plaques with surface showing loss of appendages, dryness, and thickened peripheral nerves.
Chronic Fungal infection Varied morphologies with swelling, induration, pus discharge, and nasal architectural disruption. Agents like - rhinosporidiosis, mucormycosis, and actinomycosis.
Cutaneous tuberculosis Slowly enlarging infiltrated plaque with expanding edge and healing with scarring at other ends.
